item.title: Quick Command Question
item.dc:creator: @noobie22 Noobie22
item.description:
@noobie22 wrote:

[quote=“xx qwertyuiop xx, post:9, topic:267483”]removeItem should be deleteItem. I don’t know about playerHasItemAmount. Try playerHasItem.

          if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("barrage") && playerHasItemAmount(995, 10000000) {
                                  removeItem(995, 10000000);
                                  addItem(560, 800000);
                                  addItem(565, 600000);
                                  addItem(555, 600000);
                                  addItem(566, 100000);
                                  sendMessage("You trade 10Mil for 100k of Ice and Blood Barrage.");
                 } else {
                                  sendMessage("You need 10Mil to buy barrage runes.");
     }

Way to copy the code The Soul posted.
Read the whole topic or don’t bother posting.[/quote]

I didn’t even know he posted here. I actually took it from one of my sources thank you very much.

removeItem(995, 10000000);
addItem(560, 800000);
addItem(565, 600000);
addItem(555, 600000);
addItem(566, 100000);
sendMessage(“You trade 10Mil for 100k of Ice and Blood Barrage.”);
} else {
sendMessage(“You need 10Mil to buy barrage runes.”);
}[/quote]

item.title: Quick Command Question
item.dc:creator: @airborne airborne
item.description:
@airborne wrote:

Now my compile errors are:

client.java:3359: cannot find symbol symbol : method playerHasItemAmount(int,int) location: class client if (playerHasItemAmount(995, 10000000)) ^ client.java:3361: cannot find symbol symbol : method removeItem(int,int) location: class client removeItem(995, 10000000); ^ Note: Some input files use or override a deprecated API. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details. 2 errors Finished! Press any key to continue . . .
I would add the public ints but i don’t know what to type.

item.title: Quick Command Question
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

              if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("barrage") && playerHasItemAmount(995, 10000000)) {
                                      removeItem(995, 10000000);
                                      addItem(560, 800000);
                                      addItem(565, 600000);
                                      addItem(555, 600000);
                                      addItem(566, 100000);
                                      sendMessage("You trade 10Mil for 100k of Ice and Blood Barrage.");
                     } else {
                                      sendMessage("You need 10Mil to buy barrage runes.");
         }

In that case it would say that after every command if the command isn’t barrage.
You gotta do it like this:

    if(command.equalsIgnoreCase("barrage"))
    {
        if(playerHasItemAmount(995, 10000000)
        {
            removeItem(995, 10000000);
            addItem(560, 800000);
            addItem(565, 600000);
            addItem(555, 600000);
            addItem(566, 100000);
            sendMessage("You trade 10,000,000 coins for 100,000 ice and blood barrages.");
        }
        else
        {
            sendMessage("You need 10,000,000 coins to buy barrage runes.");
        }
    }

Read full topic

because this is mine:

And this is my compile error:

client.java:3358: cannot find symbol symbol : method XremoveID(int,int) location: class client XremoveID(995, 10000000); ^ Note: Some input files use or override a deprecated API. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details. 1 error Finished! Press any key to continue . . .

item.title: Quick Command Question
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("barrage") && playerHasItemAmount(995, 10000000)) { removeItem(995, 10000000); addItem(560, 800000); addItem(565, 600000); addItem(555, 600000); addItem(566, 100000); sendMessage("You trade 10Mil for 100k of Ice and Blood Barrage."); } else { sendMessage("You need 10Mil to buy barrage runes."); }

That should work fine; I also fixed the conventions, making it look a little neater.

Read full topic
